homepage.title: The Interactive Platform for Understanding Geological Storage of CO₂ helps you understand CO₂ storage.

box1.title: CO₂ capture
box1.description: CO₂ is directly captured from large emitters before being released in the atmosphere

box2.title: CO₂ compression & injection
box2.description: Captured CO₂ is compressed to liquid or supercritical form and injected in the subsurface at min. depth env. 700-800m

box3.title: CO₂ storage
box3.description: CO₂ is injected in a porous geological layer that is called reservoir

box4.title: CO₂ migration
box4.description: The injected CO₂ is less dense than the existing water in the pores and starts migrating upwards

box5.title: CO₂ trapping
box5.description: The buoyant CO₂ is stopped from escaping to the surface thanks to the existence of the caprock, another geological layer that acts as a hydromechanical barrier

page_1.title: Why Geological Carbon Storage ?
page_1.text_1: CO₂ is a major greenhouse gas. Geological storage helps reduce emissions from heavy industries (e.g., steel, cement, power plants) that are difficult to decarbonize.
page_1.text_2: Most climate models show we can’t reach net-zero emissions without some form of carbon capture and storage, especially for hard-to-abate sectors.
page_1.text_3: Deep geological formations (like depleted oil and gas fields or deep saline aquifers) can trap CO₂ for thousands to millions of years.

page_2.title: What is Geological Carbon Storage?
page_2.text_1: CO₂ is captured from industrial processes or directly from the air using technologies like chemical absorption or adsorption.
page_2.text_2: The captured CO₂ is compressed into a supercritical fluid and transported via pipelines or ships to storage sites.
page_2.text_3: At the storage site, CO₂ is injected deep underground (typically 800 meters or more) into porous rock formations sealed by impermeable cap rocks.
page_2.text_4: Advanced monitoring techniques (like seismic surveys and well logging) ensure the CO₂ remains securely stored and detect any potential leaks.

page_3.title:
GCS
in the World
page_3.text_1: Several large-scale geological carbon storage projects are operational worldwide, demonstrating the feasibility and safety of this technology.
page_3.image_alt: Map of global geological carbon storage projects

project_1.name: Sleipner (Norway)
project_1.description: Operational since 1996, Sleipner is one of the longest-running CCS projects, injecting about 1 million tonnes of CO₂ annually into a saline aquifer beneath the North Sea.

project_2.name: Quest (Canada)
project_2.description: Since 2015, Quest has captured and stored over 5 million tonnes of CO₂ from oil sands operations in Alberta, showcasing CCS in the energy sector.

project_3.name: Gorgon (Australia)
project_3.description: The Gorgon project began injecting CO₂ in 2019, aiming to store up to 4 million tonnes per year from its LNG operations.

page_4.title: Geological Carbon Storage in Switzerland
page_4.text_1: Switzerland is actively exploring geological carbon storage as part of its climate strategy, with several initiatives and studies underway.

initiative_1.name: Swiss CCS Research
initiative_1.description: Swiss research institutions are conducting studies on the feasibility of CO₂ storage in deep saline aquifers and depleted oil and gas fields.

initiative_2.name: Pilot Projects
initiative_2.description: Pilot projects are being developed to test CO₂ capture and storage technologies in various industrial sectors.

initiative_3.name: Regulatory Framework
initiative_3.description: Switzerland is working on establishing a regulatory framework to ensure the safe and effective implementation of geological carbon storage.
